1. Some have long been disgusted with the suffering of birth and death and give rise to the aspiration for enlightenment out of aversion to suffering, and attain the fruits of the Three Vehicles and One Vehicle,
called the wisdom of self-realized sages, also called the wisdom of the Buddha, natural wisdom, and teacherless wisdom.
2. Relying on the prior realization of others, one is exhorted to know the root of suffering in order to be able to give rise to the aspiration for enlightenment.
Those who give rise to the aspiration for enlightenment have these two kinds.
If it is said that one must rely on the prior Buddhas to give rise to the aspiration for enlightenment, then there is the fault of permanence, which is the same as the eternalism of non-Buddhists.
Then, who is the teacher of the prior realization of others?
Transmitting to each other, they are not apart from eternalism.

If there is an eternally existing Buddha of the past who is the teacher of the transmission, then the self-nature of the ancient Buddha is truly not following delusion, so one cannot tread on his ancient traces, because true self is eternally true, and cannot be made to follow birth and death.
Then birth and death is eternally birth and death, and the Buddha is eternally the Buddha.
If sentient beings definitely have birth and death, birth and death would always be birth and death, and cannot be attained as true.
This is the view of annihilation.
These two kinds are both not apart from annihilation and permanence.
For all sentient beings, birth and death have no nature, originally there is no birth and death, yet mistakenly conceive of birth and death, originally not birth and death.
All buddhas are originally without self-nature, therefore there is truly no enlightenment and no nirvana, yet sentient beings mistakenly think that buddhas have enlightenment and nirvana.

If there are sentient beings who can understand in this way, it is called giving rise to the mind, it is called buddhas, it is called seeing the path, and is able to enlighten all sentient beings, this is called one who penetrates ignorance.
Ignorance is originally non-existent, and buddhas are also non-existent, this is called the enlightened one.

But only with the wondrous wisdom that is without reliance, without basis, and without nature, is able to respond to sounds and manifest form bodies, and is able to teach sentient beings with this principle, this is called great compassion.
Therefore, it is impossible to have realization, joy, aversion, grasping, rejection, past, present, true, or false in the mind of enlightenment.
Thus, the mind of enlightenment is not covered by the long night of ignorance.
The sutra says the water of craving moistens because birth exists due to craving.
The irrigation of self-conceit refers to the eight kinds of conceit:
1. conceit, 2. great conceit, 3. extreme conceit, 4. self-conceit, 5. conceit of superiority, 6. conceit of inferiority, 7. false conceit, 8. arrogant conceit.
The growth of the net of views refers to the five views and the sixty-two views, etc.
The birth of the sprout of name-and-form means that due to the views, craving arises, and it arises together with name-and-form.

The growth of name-and-form gives rise to the five faculties means that due to name-and-form, the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and body correspond to name-and-form to produce contact, and contact produces feeling.
The body's tactile objects have twelve kinds, namely rough, smooth, light, heavy, cold, hot, hunger, thirst, solidity, moisture, warmth, and movement.

The eye's visible objects have twenty-five kinds of tactile objects, namely blue, yellow, red, white, long, short, square, round, high, low, regular, irregular, light, shadow, brightness, darkness, smoke, clouds, dust, mist, coarse, subtle, distant, and empty visible objects.

The ear's sounds have eleven kinds of tactile objects, namely agreeable, disagreeable, both, contradictory, caused by the great elements that are felt, caused by the great elements that are not felt, caused by the great elements that are both, sounds produced by the world's consensus, sounds conceived by discrimination, sounds included in the words of the sages, and sounds not included in the words of the sages.
The nose has six kinds of smells as tactile objects, namely good, bad, neutral, mixed, innate, and transformed.
Flavors have twelve kinds of tactile objects, namely bitter, sour, sweet, spicy, salty, bland, agreeable, disagreeable, both, contradictory, mixed, innate, and transformed.
The sixty-six kinds of mental phenomena obtained above the five roots are named by the thinking mind.

When the mind gives rise to intention, the mental consciousness follows the names that appear in the five roots and is called contact. The mental root follows and grasps them and is called feeling. Not letting go of feeling is called craving. Craving increases and grasps, and grasping increases existence.

Having been born, it takes the sixty-six kinds of mental phenomena that were the objects of the mental consciousness above the six roots and forms the five-aggregate body in the various destinies as birth.
Having been born, decaying is called old age, and ending is called death. At the time of death, various torments arise, up to sorrow, lamentation, suffering, and distress all come together.
For this cause and condition, there is accumulation - the one and a half lines of text after this clarify that dependent origination has no substance and is mistakenly called birth and death.
One should contemplate in accordance with the substance of dependent origination in this way.

It clarifies that the substance of the twelve links of dependent origination is something sentient beings emotionally have but is actually logically nonexistent. If one skillfully understands the logical nonexistence of the nature of dependent origination, then birth and death are not birth and death.

This section above clarifies that the twelve links of dependent origination exist due to attachment to self. If one contemplates non-self, one can be free from grasping and the false conditions will become the great wisdom of the Dharma realm, the self-nature of dependent origination without action.
The second section has ten and a half lines of text, clarifying the part where the Bodhisattva thinks of all sentient beings.
Delusion about the ultimate truth is called ignorance.
The results of karmic activity are the basis of action.
The initial mind is consciousness. It clarifies that because of delusion about the ultimate truth, it is called ignorance.
The true as the false all have dependent retribution. With dependent retribution, there are name-and-form.

In order to delude the true appearance, the emotional consciousness grasps the realm, together with feeling, perception, mental formations, consciousness, and the six sense faculties, it is grasped simultaneously, and is called the aggregates.
Because the aggregates are indestructible, they are called karma.

The conscious mind is the main factor. The six sense faculties and objects are combined to become the object of cognition. The four graspings arise together. The emotions are the form and objects of the mind. The emotional consciousness is the subjective cognition. The feelings follow it and are called formations.
Seeking, thinking, and worrying confuse one's pure wisdom and are called the aggregates.
The combination of the three things of the six sense faculties, objects, and consciousness is called contact.
Based on these five aggregates corresponding to the six sense faculties, the twelve links exist simultaneously above the emotional consciousness.
The following twelve links are as explained in the sutra text.
Thus far, this section clarifies how, by being deluded about the ultimate truth, the five aggregates arise, and how the twelve links of dependent arising arise together based on the five aggregates.
The third section has seven and a half lines of text, clarifying that all that exists in the three realms is only one mind.

It clarifies that the twelve links arise from one mind, because following the matter of craving and delusion of the true mind, the deluded mind arises as thought. Thought deviates from wisdom and falsely discriminates as consciousness. What is discriminated by the deluded mind is consciousness, and the object of consciousness is action.
Delusion regarding action refers to the object of consciousness.
It is called ignorance because it is considered to truly exist.
Because the mind is ignorant, it gives rise to name-and-form.

From name-and-form, the six sense faculties, and the deluded mind, the three things come together to give rise to contact. The correct contact corresponds to discrimination and attachment, which is feeling. The rest is complete in the sutra itself.

Above this, mind and object, the six sense faculties, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, old age and death, all occur simultaneously, without a prior or posterior substance. Delusion creates prior and posterior. Delusion regarding the principle and wisdom of the Tathagata originally has no creator, so it gives rise to various sufferings horizontally, and the waves of suffering flow without ceasing.

The fourth section has fifteen and a half lines of text, clarifying that both ignorance and the twelve links of dependent origination have two kinds of karma. First, due to ignorance, it causes all sentient beings to be confused about the self-nature of the wisdom of non-action and the Dharma realm;
second, because ignorance gives rise to dependent origination, it causes the conditions of thought and activity to be produced, therefore it is said to be the cause of giving rise to activity.

Activity also has two kinds of karma. First, due to confusion about the wisdom of the Dharma realm, it grasps and forms the retribution of the future; second, due to the deluded activity of thought, the seeds of consciousness are produced.
Therefore, the sÅ«tra says, It is the cause of giving rise to consciousness.

Consciousness also has two kinds of karma. First, due to confusion about the seeds of fundamental wisdom, deluded consciousness arises and causes the karma of all beings to continue without interruption;

second, due to confusion about the nameless subtle merits of the universal light wisdom of the fundamental source, the coarse name-and-form of the karma of birth and death formed by the seeds of consciousness arises.

As for name-and-form also having two kinds of karma, first, because of consciousness, there is name-and-form, and because of name-and-form, there is consciousness, thus it is said they mutually assist each other;
second, because of name-and-form, it appears before the six sense organs, able to cause the emotional consciousness in the six sense organs to grasp it.

As for the six sense organs also having two kinds of karma, first, because of delusion about the principle of the single characteristic of the essence of signlessness, each according to a different object grasps the different characteristics of form, sound, etc.;
second, because the six sense organs manifest objects, the emotional consciousness arises in opposition to them, thus it is said it acts as the cause of production for contact.
As for contact also having two kinds of karma, first, because of contact able to delude the object, it can receive present-world dust and form various joys and angers;
second, because of receiving present-world dust, it forms the result of suffering in the future.
As for feeling also having two kinds of karma, first, because of delusion about the emptiness of all dharmas, it can experience things such as love and hatred;
second, it acts as the cause of production for craving.
What follows is complete in the text.
This section on dependent origination all begins with the ignorance of the principle of reality, which is the root.
The fifth section has four and a half lines of text, divided into two parts.

The first part, from Buddha's disciples, here ignorance conditions formations... to assist in completion, has two lines of text, clarifying that the eleven factors of existence such as ignorance are all due to the fundamental wisdom being deluded, using the deluded mind to form consciousness, and mutually assisting each other to form.
In each condition there are twelve, mutually assisting each other in their essence, totaling one hundred and forty-four.
In the three worlds above there are one hundred and forty-four each, totaling four hundred and thirty-two.
All due to the fundamental true wisdom being deluded, called ignorance.
Within ignorance, the five aggregates are born due to the three things of objects, the six sense faculties, and consciousness.
Using the five aggregates to correspond with the six sense faculties, all contacts arise, with the sixth consciousness as the main factor.

And in accordance with the faculties, objects, and consciousness, it is able to create various causes and conditions for the karma of birth and death, up to the eighty-four thousand afflictions arising from this.
As for the eighty-four thousand afflictions, their names and numbers will be fully explained in the chapter on the light and merits of the minor marks.

But if one simply understands that the three things of consciousness, mind, faculties, and objects have a single nature, and the single nature is called no nature, and penetrates the principle of no nature with the wisdom of universal light, universally sealing all objects, the wonderful function is always tranquil, and ignorance becomes wisdom. All of this is called the ocean of universal wisdom.
The two and a half lines of text below the extinction of ignorance explain the conditions for attaining liberation by penetrating ignorance, as the text itself fully explains.
The sixth section has three and a half lines of text, explaining that the three things of ignorance, craving, and grasping are not cut off, which is the path of afflictions.
The two things of karmic action and existence are not cut off, which is the path of karma.
The remaining parts refer to name-and-form, contact, feeling, birth, old age, sickness, death, sorrow, lamentation, etc., which are the path of suffering.

In the past, present, and future three periods of time, when the afflictions of the three sections are eliminated, there are no three periods of time or three sections of afflictions, apart from self and what belongs to self, there is only birth and cessation.
Like a bundle of reeds clarifies that although there is discrimination and similar birth and cessation, the middle is understood to be empty and non-existent.
Like a bundle of reeds, although its appearance exists, each part is empty in the middle.
It clarifies that although the six sense faculties and objects exist, the Dharma eye is always empty. This clarifies the contemplation and penetration.
The seventh section has two and a half lines of scripture.

It says, Next, the condition of ignorance gives rise to karmic activity. There are three periods of time of ignorance. The condition of ignorance giving rise to karmic activity is in the present thought. The past is the previously perceived object.
The sÅ«tra says, This contemplates the consciousness of the past.

Up to the reception of this contemplation of the present as consciousness reception, this is the present within the future thought, in order to clarify the consciousness reception and distinguish the reception of present events.

Craving up to existence, this contemplates the future, because craving has two events that are the future within the future thought, and because this is the future consciousness reception within the future thought, only later is it considered to be truly existent, because it becomes the attachment of craving.

As for thus it continues in succession after this, this is because the ignorance conditions the formations, consciousness, reception, craving, and existence, forming the uninterrupted succession of the fruits of the karma of the three periods of time.
But when ignorance ceases, then the formations cease, and then the consciousness, reception, craving, and existence, and the twelve links of dependent origination, all cease.

As for this is the contemplation of the cessation of dependence, it clarifies that the twelve links of dependent origination are only eliminated through contemplation. This includes the meaning of the six characteristics.
The eighth section has two and a half lines of scripture, which in total clarify that the twelve links of dependent origination together form the three kinds of suffering.

The first, ignorance and karmic formations, as well as the six sense faculties, are the suffering of formations. This is because the deluded mind clings to objects without rest, so it is the suffering of formations.
The second, contact and feeling, are the suffering of suffering. It clarifies that feeling various contacts gives rise to love and hatred, and suffering.
When feeling contacts, there is suffering. Adding craving and aversion, suffering is added to suffering.

The remaining are the suffering of change. Among the twelve links of dependent origination, from name-and-form, consciousness, grasping, craving, becoming, birth, old age, sickness, and death, the seven are the suffering of change.
One only observes that when ignorance ceases, karmic formations cease, and the three sufferings cease, the twelve links of dependent origination cease.
The ninth section has five lines of scripture, clarifying three sections of the conditions for the cessation and arising of the twelve links of dependent origination.
First, it clarifies that ignorance conditions karmic formations, which is the meaning of arising. Without ignorance, karmic formations also do not exist. The rest are also like this.
Second, the karmic formations conditioned by ignorance are the meaning of bondage.

The cessation of ignorance and the cessation of karmic formations refer to the cessation of bondage, which is the meaning of severing afflictions, because it is liberation, and because it is associated with great wisdom.

The three aspects of ignorance as a condition for karmic formations refer to the practice of contemplating the absence of anything, which is the power of the practice of arising contemplation, because the contemplation of conditions follows the absence of anything in the intrinsic nature of the twelve links of dependent origination.
The cessation of ignorance and the cessation of karmic formations is because of contemplating the absence of substance in the twelve links of existence.
The rest is the same.
In general, the twelve links of dependent origination are only the absence of ignorance, which is the absence of the twelve links of dependent origination.

The tenth section has four and a half lines of text, clarifying the observation of the twelve links of dependent origination in terms of ten kinds of reverse and forward, which are all included in one mind. It is only due to the different sufferings and joys of one's own karma that there are distinctions, but they are not apart from the twelve links of existence.
But it is the same as the three paths that are not severed, namely, mind, objects, and ignorance. If these three are absent, the rest will all be absent by themselves.
If one does not sever them, the three kinds of suffering will accumulate, namely the suffering of change, the suffering of suffering, and the suffering of separation.
As for severing them, it is because ignorance itself becomes the wondrous function of non-suffering and the wisdom of principle.
The above is the division of ten kinds of reverse and forward contemplation of the twelve links of dependent origination within the third section.

The fourth section has seven and a half lines of text, clarifying that after performing the ten kinds of reverse and forward contemplation of the twelve links of dependent origination, one has already penetrated the nature of dependent origination itself being unborn, and thus attains the three gates of liberation.

The three gates of liberation are: First, contemplating the twelve links of dependent origination themselves as empty and without action, all self-nature extinguished, ultimately liberated, attaining the gate of liberation of emptiness.
Second, not finding even the slightest dharma that can be attained, one then attains the gate of liberation of signlessness.

Third, having attained the two gates of emptiness and signlessness, there are no further wishes or requests. Only with great compassion, one teaches and transforms all sentient beings, causing them to attain ultimate liberation and the gate of wishless liberation.
The rest is fully contained in the text itself.
The fifth section has ten and a half lines of scripture, clarifying that the bodhisattvas of this stage attain the three gates of liberation and increase their great compassion.
Within this section, it is further divided into two parts.

From Buddha's disciple, this bodhisattva... up to also not ultimately extinguishing all conditioned activities, there are five and a half lines of scripture, clarifying the observation that all conditioned phenomena are impermanent and greatly to be detested. In order to perfect sentient beings, one also does not permanently extinguish conditioned activities.

From Buddha's disciple, the bodhisattva is like this... up to because it is not yet complete, there are six and a half lines of scripture, clarifying that the bodhisattva observes that conditioned phenomena have many faults and lack self-nature, yet always arouses great compassion and attains the perfection of wisdom.

As the sutra says for the sake of those who have not yet fulfilled the factors of enlightenment, it clarifies that in these six grounds one has already attained the supramundane enlightenment of emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, but has not yet attained the enlightenment of freely engaging in the ocean of Samantabhadra's practices while entering into worldly affairs with great compassion.

Again, he thought, 'All conditioned things arise when there is combination, and cease when there is no combination.'  This clarifies that when deluded emotions arise, all phenomena are impermanent and change. When emotions accord with principle, all phenomena are by nature unborn. This mind arises, and phenomena arise.
The following should be understood accordingly.

When conditions gather, they arise; when they do not gather, they do not arise. If ignorance conditions karmic activity, then it arises. If ignorance ceases, then karmic activity follows wisdom and arises. Arising is only the arising of phenomena, not impermanent transition and attachment.
The following should be understood accordingly.
Conditioned phenomena have many faults. The activities of sentient beings' consciousnesses all give rise to the suffering and pain of birth, old age, sickness, and death.
If one acts with wisdom and compassion, it is all the practice of Samantabhadra.
The following should be understood accordingly.

One will immediately attain the presence of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ means one has already transcended the wisdom of hearing, thinking, and cultivation. This wisdom of the One Vehicle is the wisdom of the Buddha, which is the ultimate, effortless, universal illuminating wisdom.
This is called the wisdom that pervades everywhere and benefits beings according to their capacities, functioning without intention and responding without thought.
The rest is as fully described in the sÅ«tra itself.

Because the factors of enlightenment are not yet complete means that the enlightenment of right awakening is accomplished from the beginning of the mind, while the enlightenment of following practice is fulfilled at the end of the eleventh ground.
In the sixth section, there are six and a half lines of sÅ«tra, clarifying the section on attaining the presence of the samÄdhi of the ten emptinesses.
The samÄdhi of the emptiness of self-nature means that it is not attained through cultivation, but manifests naturally by following the principle without effort.
This is called right concentration. SamÄdhi means right and mÄdhi means concentration.
Why is sam taken to be right?
In general, for practices, sam is taken to be right.
MÄdhi means the absence of emotional cognition, which is called mÄdhi.
The manifestation of right wisdom is called the third.
Also, three means correct.
Why is it so?
Because three is yang, it is correct.

It is like in the eleventh month, one yang is born; in the twelfth month, two yangs are born; in the first month, three yangs are born, which is the first month. Takingå¯…as wood, as the sun, and as fire.
Fire is born in å¯…, and the sun is taken as wisdom.
Taking the twelfth month and first month as Gen, as a mountain, as stopping, as a gate, as a young man, and as a child, therefore the sages take it as a symbol of the Dharma.

In the first month, three yangs have already been born, which is born from the stopping of Gen, clarifying that from concentration, stopping gives rise to unconditioned right wisdom. It clarifies that this is the gate of enlightenment for entering the Way.
Gen is a child, clarifying that the stopping mind of a child can give rise to the light of the sun of great wisdom.
It is said that three means correct, and obscurity means concentration.

Because the five aggregates are obscure, then right wisdom appears. Moreover, one stillness is the character of correctness. With one-pointed stillness, the Way is correct, so by stilling in one place, nothing is not accomplished.
The samÄdhi of ultimate emptiness is because it transcends all impermanent dharmas of conditioned arising.

The samÄdhi of the foremost emptiness is clear in initially transcending the meditative absorptions of the two upper realms, and also transcends the meditative absorptions of purity and impurity of the three vehicles of the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and pure lands.
Moreover, the myriad images of the ten directions are of one nature, called the samÄdhi of the foremost emptiness.

The samÄdhi of great emptiness is because it transcends the emptiness cognized by worldly emotions, and transcends the emptiness of no-action in which the three vehicles abide, because it obtains the body born of the mind.
The samÄdhi of combined emptiness is clear because it combines with the sentient and insentient beings of the ten directions.
The samÄdhi of arising emptiness is clear because quiescence and function are sovereign.
The samÄdhi of emptiness that is not discriminated in accordance with reality is clear because there is no emotional consciousness, and because it manifests what is seen by the faculties.
Not abandoning the samÄdhi of emptiness shows the avoidance of faults and evils.
The samÄdhi of emptiness that is both abandoned and not abandoned means dwelling in the world like a lotus in water.

Taking these twelve samÄdhis as the foremost, all are not apart from the essence of the three samÄdhis of emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, and the hundred thousand samÄdhis all arise from this.
The seventh section has nine and a half lines of text, divided into three parts.
From Buddha's disciple to all completely fulfilled has three and a half lines of text, clarifying the cultivation of ten kinds of limitless mind.

From Buddha's disciple to always practicing without abandoning has four lines of text, clarifying the following of the Buddha's enlightenment, not fearing heterodox theories, and entering the Buddha's wisdom ground.

From Buddha's disciple to because of following without contradiction has two and a half lines of text, clarifying the practice of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ by the bodhisattva dwelling in this stage and attaining the forbearance of following.
The sutra says not fearing heterodox theories refers to the heterodox theories of humans, gods, non-Buddhists, and the three vehicles.
Entering the stage of the Buddha's wisdom clarifies that one enters the stage of discriminating wisdom from fundamental wisdom.
Departing from the path of the two vehicles means that the two vehicles eliminate afflictions to realize emptiness, while bodhisattvas penetrate afflictions to form the ocean of wisdom.

None of the demons of afflictions can obstruct those who proceed to the Buddha's wisdom clarifies that the demon of afflictions is the cause of birth and death, while the demon of the aggregates and the demon of death are the fruits of birth and death, and the heavenly demon is the condition of birth and death.
Abiding in the wisdom of the bodhisattvas refers to all the discriminating wisdoms that accord with the world.

Buddha's disciples, bodhisattvas abiding in this stage of Presence attain the superior practice of the perfection of wisdom clarifies that the bodhisattvas of this stage thoroughly contemplate the arising and cessation of all conditioned phenomena in the three realms, and attain the wisdom of the world and beyond the world, thus it is called superior.

Third, the clear and beneficial concordant forbearance, according to the five forbearances, is the third concordant forbearance. If according to the ten forbearances, it is the second concordant forbearance.

Like the five forbearances in the three vehicles: first, the forbearance of subjugation; second, the forbearance of faith; third, the concordant forbearance; fourth, the forbearance of no birth; fifth, the forbearance of quiescent extinction.

Like the three vehicles, the three good bodhisattvas before the grounds attain the forbearance of subjugation, the fifth ground attains the forbearance of faith, the sixth ground the concordant forbearance, the eighth ground the forbearance of no birth, and the tenth ground the forbearance of quiescent extinction.
The ten forbearances are complete in the sutra text.

In this one vehicle teaching, using the ten perfections, the five stages of the ten abodes, ten practices, ten dedications, ten grounds, and eleventh ground are cultivated and practiced, with the ten perfections mutually serving as primary and secondary in each stage.

Above the five positions, there are five hundred practices, each gradually becoming more subtle. Speaking in terms of the meaning of the six characteristics of totality and distinction, time, days, years, and months are all like this, just like the imperial net, with layers upon layers reflecting each other, and one and many, same and different, all without changing.
The eighth section has twenty-seven and a half lines of scripture, which are divided into six parts.

The first part, from Buddha's disciple to becoming even more pure and bright, has nine lines of scripture, explaining the part about seeing many Buddhas through the power of vows and making offerings to the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha.
The second part, from It is like true gold to cannot be destroyed by the four kinds of demonic paths, has six lines of scripture, explaining the part about using analogies to illustrate the Dharma.

The third part, from This bodhisattva's ten perfections to the sixth ground of direct presence, has two and a half lines of scripture, explaining the part about the Dharma gates cultivated by the bodhisattvas on this ground.

Fourth, from The Bodhisattva dwelling in this ground to for the sake of omniscience, there are about six lines of text, clarifying the position of the Bodhisattva receiving the position and being able to teach and transform all sentient beings.
Fifth, from This Bodhisattva to the verse, there are four lines of text, clarifying the position of the Bodhisattva seeing the Buddhas extensively through samÄdhi.
Sixth, from the first line of verse to I have already proclaimed it for the Buddha's disciples, there are forty-four lines of verse, restating the previous Dharma, as is clear in the text itself.
The above eight sections have explained the sixth ground of Presence.
This ground is skillfully penetrating the conditioned arising that produces mundane and supramundane wisdom.
The seventh ground of far-reaching is accomplishing the perfection of skillful means and entering the wisdom and compassion of supramundane wisdom within the mundane.
The seventh ground of far-reaching, in explaining this ground, the five aspects are as before.
First, explaining the name of the ground: Why is it called the Ground of Far-reaching?

Because this ground practices the perfection of skillful means, and within the sixth ground, through the three concentrations of emptiness, manifests immeasurable wisdom doors of non-action, able to enter immeasurable realms of sentient beings, enter immeasurable activities of teaching and transforming sentient beings, and enter the immeasurable network of worlds.
Using the wisdom of non-action to enter all worldly realms, equally engaging in the practices of sentient beings to universally pervade everywhere, it is therefore called the Ground of Far-reaching.
In order to enter worldly practices to be universally vast and extensive, it is called the Ground of Far-reaching.
Second, clarifying what practices are cultivated in this ground: In this ground, one cultivates the perfection of skillful means.

By giving rise to the gates of liberation of emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, one is able to enter the world and engage in the myriad practices of sentient beings, yet without leaving the world or following birth and death, and greatly cultivating compassion, it is therefore called the perfection of skillful means.

As for the third, the symbolism of Sudhana, the knowledge-friends he sees in this stage are in the Buddha's assembly, which clarifies not leaving the essence of enlightenment and practicing various practices.

The name Flowering Tree symbolizes the tree of wondrous wisdom without characteristics blooming the flowers of Samantabhadra's practices, and also blooming the flowers of ignorance and practices of all sentient beings, causing them to become the flowers of Samantabhadra's practices. It is to symbolize the seventh stage of accomplishing worldly practices and perfecting the gate of compassion.
His body is within the jeweled tree pavilion, on a lion seat made of wondrous jewels, symbolizing the jeweled trees as various practices, clarifying the dependent environment.
The jeweled trees forming the shape of a pavilion clarifies the wisdom that accords with practices.
The wondrous jeweled lion seat symbolizes the fearless practices of wondrous function.

As for Sudhana attaining the bodhisattva's liberation of vast joy, it clarifies that the bodhisattvas of this ground accomplish the practices of great compassion, universally able to skillfully teach and transform sentient beings, joyful without weariness.
Not dwelling in either defilement or purity, it is called liberation.
The seventh ground is the teachings to be given, and this is the practice of the bodhisattvas within the seventh ground, thus it is named one's own abode to illustrate it.

Fourth, clarifying what kind of liberation this ground attains within the three realms, this ground clarifies the method of liberation of abiding in all worldly practices, skillfully benefiting beings, and not being tainted by worldly dharmas.
It is also the bodhisattva's liberation of vast joy attained by Sudhana.
As the sutra says, In this seventh ground, the practices with effort are fulfilled, and one attains entry into the conduct of mastery of wisdom.

It also says, In the first ground, because one vows to seek to fulfill all Buddha Dharmas, in the second ground one is free from mental defilements, in the third ground one's vows increase and one attains the light of the Dharma, in the fourth ground one enters the path, in the fifth ground one accords with worldly activities, in the sixth ground one enters the extremely profound Dharma gates, in the seventh ground one gives rise to all Buddha Dharmas and thus also fulfills the factors of enlightenment.
